```{r}

library(imager)
library(ggplot2)

# Define the path to your image
img_path <- "C:/Users/jacob/OneDrive/Desktop/Project X/R Studio Images/Screenshot 2024-08-19 074934.png"

# Load the image
img <- load.image(img_path)

# Display the image
plot(img, main="Loaded Image")

# Convert the image to a data frame of pixel values
img_data <- as.data.frame(img, wide = "c")  # 'wide = "c"' keeps RGB channels separate

# Define a simple affine transformation matrix (scaling + translation)
transformation_matrix <- matrix(c(1, 0, 20,   # x' = x + 20 (translation)
                                  0, 1, 20),  # y' = y + 20 (translation)
                                nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE)

# Apply the affine transformation to the x and y coordinates
img_data_transformed <- img_data
img_data_transformed$x <- transformation_matrix[1,1] * img_data$x + transformation_matrix[1,2] * img_data$y + transformation_matrix[1,3]
img_data_transformed$y <- transformation_matrix[2,1] * img_data$x + transformation_matrix[2,2] * img_data$y + transformation_matrix[2,3]

# Plot the transformed image using small points
ggplot(img_data_transformed, aes(x = x, y = y, color = rgb(c.1, c.2, c.3))) +
  geom_point(size = 0.1) +  # Small points
  scale_color_identity() +  # Use the RGB colors as is
  coord_fixed() +           # Keep the aspect ratio fixed
  theme_void() +            # Remove axis labels and ticks
  ggtitle("Transformed Image with Affine Transformation")


```
